body:
Looks like a bug,
The current regex:
https://regex101.com/r/UHNuhL/1
https://regex101.com/r/UHNuhL/2

\, ], ^,  cannot be used, as they would not give a valid action method.

What I dont understand - this seems to have worked, or why look for dashes?
https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/issues/1296

The action IDs are converted to dashed lowercase (that is by design that IDs are dashed-lowercase) so your URL is `<apiUrl>/auth/sso-attributes`. In order to have it as `ssoAttributes` you have to specify non-automatic rule such as:

```php
'auth/ssoAttributes' => 'auth/auth/sso-attributes'
```

@samdark I have tried this, also. Sorry I forgot to mention.

When I try to access `<apiUrl>/auth/sso-attributes`, I get a standard 404 error.

But in this case the code doesn't even reach the `Controller::createAction()` method and fails still in the `UrlRule::parseRequest()` method. So I thought the dash wasn't suppose to compose the url and assumed `ssoAttributes` would be the correct endpoint as it was in Yii 1.1. Seems I assumed wrong. ~(up to now)~ ðŸ˜…

The test it returns false is here:
https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/efe8d48f156e9e76994a2322cdd0fb4d68bd8f6a/framework/web/UrlRule.php#L412-L414

I think `preg_match('/^[a-z0-9\\-_]+$/', $id)` should not contain double backslash at all - because:

* double backslash = explicit character `\`, means URL like `my\url` would be accepted (wrong).
* single backslash = escaping, would allow following character translated as REGEX modifier, e.g. `\-` would allow characters range up to the `-` character (wrong)

My guess is that by removing it would not break anything for first option because writing action name like `function actionMy\Action(){...}` is not possible and for the second option it would only fix unwanted buggy behaviour.

The regex as it is really makes no sense:
This is valid: 
`asd\]^_asd`
This is not :
`asd\]^_-asd`

issue.title: Fix #17507: Fixed regular expression escaping in `Controller::createAction()`
